188657.title: Remain calm and be prepared to wait.  Showing impatience can increase pressure to pay.  Use any or all of these statements to help you explain why you won't pay.

nodes.text: Remain courteous, respectful and if possible friendly
Make it clear that your company does not allow you to make payments of this kind / that your head office doesn’t allow me to pay any fee that isn’t official
Ask for name and official title of person asking and any identity number
State that you would need an official receipt if you were to pay the fee
Ask to speak to the supervisor/manager of the person making the demand to discuss why you cant pay
Mention that you will contact the embassy / consulate to discuss / report the issue
Explain that you must call your company first to report the issue and to get permission to pay the fee
Take notes or make mental note of the conversations and the time and place for a later report
Report it
Yes

Being asked to pay a small sum of money to an official as a fine can sometimes be a facilitation payment in disguise. However, as this is a published fine and you will get a receipt it is unlikely to be a facilitation payment in this instance.  Be cautious though and if you are in any doubt do not pay.

We make no distinction between facilitation payments and bribes, no matter how small the amount. Facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.
Obtain a receipt detailing the reason for and the amount of the charge.
Record the transaction appropriately.
If you are in any doubt do not pay.

Report any suspicion or evidence of this behaviour immediately to your legal team.
Do not discuss boycotting customers or suppliers or any other competitively sensitive information any further.  Leave the meeting or the event if it is happening.
